title: File for divorce before deployment, do I have to be preset when te finalized papers come in at the 6 month window in California
question: We have no children, no debt, nothing joint no property. We want to file 1 month before I deploy which is in a few weeks. After we file I will be deployed after for a year.
question_tags: Divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Divorce and bankruptcy,Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Divorce and family,Family law
answers:
Yes, but its not as simple as just filing that way. If you truly have noting and just want to be restored to the status of single person, then you may qualify for a summary dissolution which involves less paperwork. Or she can file and then do a default without your participation. HOWEVER, since it seems uncontested and you both are cooperating, I HIGHLY SUGGEST that you both see an experienced family law attorney to discuss all your rights and obligations.

Best of luck, BUT MOST IMPORTANT, THANK YOU FOR YOUR SERVICE.

I know this answer is short and simple, but if you could be so kind and log back in and mark it as HELPFUL and/or BEST ANSWER, or both, that would help me track my contributions to this site.

If the two of you have already worked out what will happen to the assets and debts, and can come to an agreement about support there is no reason you can’t file the divorce and then deploy. Just let the lawyer know how to get in touch in case it’s necessary. Once the judgment becomes final, your attorney can forward the judgment to you.
Fair winds and following seas….
Good luck.
If you found this answer helpful, let me know by clicking the "Mark as Helpful" button at the bottom of this answer or select it as Best Answer. It’s easy and appreciated. We can be visited on the web at http://bortonpetrini.com/sandiego.htm or call 619-232-2424

if both spouses agree to the result of who gets what, who pays what then the two of you should show up at your local courthouse together and see the Family Law Facilitator who can assist in processing the paperwork at no charge to you. If done properly then you will not need to be present when the marriage is dissolved. The documents processed now and signed by both parties and the Judge will then state the marriage is dissolved [you are divorced] on a certain date which is usually the six month anniversary of the court acquiring jurisdiction over both of you.

Thanks for your service to our country.

So long as it is agreeable between you and your spouse, and each of you comply with your disclosure requirements, and both of you sign the Stipulated Judgment, it is possible. You would best consult with an experienced Family Law Attorney and/or a volunteer lawyer in your Supeior Court's Self-Help Clinic to ensure that the documents are properly prepared and filed.
